test_metadata.test_title: Corruption, Integrity and Transparency - Practice MCQ Test
test_metadata.subject: Ethics, Integrity and Aptitude
test_metadata.sub_topic: Types, Causes, Prevention, Institutions, Integrity Systems
test_metadata.description: UPSC-style MCQs on nature of corruption, integrity, transparency mechanisms and institutional frameworks for ethical governance.

questions.question_text: In the context of public life, corruption can be best defined as:

options.option_text: Use of public office for public welfare
Use of public power for private gain in violation of rules and public interest
Strict adherence to rules and procedures
Voluntary work done for the community

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT typically considered a form of corruption in public administration?

options.option_text: Bribery
Embezzlement of public funds
Favouritism and nepotism
Transparent application of merit-based criteria

questions.question_text: Petty corruption is generally associated with which of the following situations?

options.option_text: Large-scale policy manipulation by top officials
Small bribes demanded by lower-level officials for routine services
Political funding at the national level
International tax evasion by corporations

questions.question_text: Grand corruption is best described as corruption that:

options.option_text: Occurs only at village level
Involves large sums, high-level officials and distortion of major policies or projects
Is limited to minor speeding fines
Is confined to private sector employees only

questions.question_text: Which one of the following is MOST accurately an example of 'nepotism' in public office?

options.option_text: Awarding contracts through open competitive bidding
Appointing close relatives to positions regardless of merit
Implementing reservation policy as per law
Recruiting candidates through public examination

questions.question_text: Conflict of interest in public life occurs when:

options.option_text: A public servant follows the code of conduct
Personal interests of a public official may improperly influence the performance of official duties
There is a disagreement between two departments
A policy has both advantages and disadvantages

questions.question_text: Which of the following structural factors can contribute to corruption in public administration?

options.option_text: Transparent procedures and strong oversight
Low discretion and high accountability
High discretion, low accountability and complex procedures
Simplified rules and citizen charters

questions.question_text: From an ethical perspective, 'integrity' in public service refers to:

options.option_text: Ability to manipulate rules smartly
Consistency of actions, values and decisions with moral and ethical principles
Flexibility in ignoring rules for profit
Only technical competence without moral standards

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a key component of an effective integrity system in governance?

options.option_text: Codes of conduct and ethics
Transparent procedures and RTI mechanisms
Strong oversight institutions and sanctions
Unregulated discretionary powers with no documentation

questions.question_text: Which of the following mechanisms directly promotes transparency in administration?

options.option_text: Secret oral instructions
Proactive disclosure of information and Right to Information regimes
Closed-door decision-making with no records
Suppression of audit reports

questions.question_text: The term 'speed money' generally refers to which type of corruption?

options.option_text: Bribes paid to get illegal favours
Bribes paid to expedite legitimate services that are due to the citizen
Legal service charges prescribed by rules
Court-imposed fines for traffic offences

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes 'state capture' in the context of corruption?

options.option_text: Citizens capturing government offices physically
Powerful private interests influencing laws, policies and regulations to their advantage
Routine petty bribery at local offices
Only embezzlement of funds by clerks

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of 'institutional corruption' rather than only individual misconduct?

options.option_text: A single officer demanding bribes
Organised collusion between officials and contractors embedded in the functioning of a department
Accidental calculation error by an officer
Isolated instance of misbehaviour by a clerk

questions.question_text: From an ethical point of view, which of the following is the BEST long-term strategy to reduce corruption?

options.option_text: Increasing opportunities to exercise discretion without oversight
Combining legal enforcement with systemic reforms and value-based education
Relying solely on occasional raids
Ignoring corruption if it speeds up decisions

questions.question_text: Which one of the following personal factors increases vulnerability of an official to corrupt practices?

options.option_text: Strong internal moral compass
Commitment to public service values
Lifestyle far beyond legitimate income and desire for quick enrichment
Respect for rule of law

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of 'preventive vigilance' in public organisations?

options.option_text: Punishing officials after corruption is detected
Simplifying procedures and rotating sensitive staff positions to reduce opportunities for corruption
Ignoring repeated complaints
Keeping all rules confidential

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the MOST direct role of audit institutions in curbing corruption?

options.option_text: Framing criminal laws
Examining financial records and performance to detect irregularities and inefficiencies
Organising elections
Issuing passports to citizens

questions.question_text: From an ethical lens, 'zero tolerance' approach to corruption primarily implies that:

options.option_text: Only small cases of corruption will be ignored
Any act of corruption, however minor, is unacceptable and will attract action
Corruption is tolerated up to certain amount
Only grand corruption will be prosecuted

questions.question_text: Whistle-blower protection laws are important in anti-corruption framework because they:

options.option_text: Punish those who report wrongdoing
Provide safe channels and safeguard for individuals who expose corruption in good faith
Discourage reporting of corruption
Protect only senior officials from scrutiny

questions.question_text: Which of the following institutional features MOST directly promotes transparency in government contracting and procurement?

options.option_text: Negotiations through secret informal channels
Open competitive bidding with clear criteria and public disclosure of awards
Awarding contracts only to known associates
Absence of any documentation in tender processes

questions.question_text: From the point of view of ethics, 'gift policy' for civil servants is important because it:

options.option_text: Encourages receipt of expensive gifts from stakeholders
Sets limits and conditions to avoid undue influence and perceived bribery
Allows unrestricted acceptance of hospitality
Has no relation with integrity

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of 'facilitation payment' often discussed in ethics literature?

options.option_text: Legal fee paid for filing an application
Small informal payment to public official to complete routine tasks faster
Fine imposed by court for violation
Tax payment as per law

questions.question_text: Which of the following can be considered an 'integrity risk' in the design of a public programme?

options.option_text: Clear eligibility criteria and digital records
Ambiguous rules, cash-based benefits and weak verification systems
Automation with audit trails
Independent third-party evaluation

questions.question_text: In ethical governance, 'asset declaration' by public officials primarily seeks to:

options.option_text: Increase secrecy around financial status
Enable monitoring of disproportionate assets and enhance public trust
Discourage officials from saving money legally
Identify political loyalties of officials

questions.question_text: Transparency in decision-making reduces corruption primarily because it:

options.option_text: Conceals reasons for decisions
Exposes processes and outcomes to public scrutiny making abuse harder
Prevents citizens from questioning decisions
Eliminates need to maintain records

questions.question_text: From an ethical standpoint, 'collusive corruption' refers to a situation where:

options.option_text: Officials refuse all bribes collectively
Officials, politicians and private parties cooperate to share illicit benefits
Citizens collectively oppose corruption
Agencies coordinate to enforce anti-corruption laws

questions.question_text: Which of the following indicates an 'integrity culture' in a public organisation?

options.option_text: Tolerance of minor unethical acts as long as targets are achieved
Leadership emphasising integrity, clear codes and consistent action against misconduct
Rewards solely based on financial outcomes
Neutrality towards corrupt practices

questions.question_text: From an ethics perspective, 'moral hazard' in governance may arise when:

options.option_text: Officials face strong consequences for wrongdoing
Officials believe they can engage in misconduct without bearing the consequences
Citizens are informed about their rights
Whistle-blowers are protected

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the MOST direct ethical effect of 'impunity' for corrupt acts?

options.option_text: Strengthens rule of law
Encourages recurrence of corruption by signalling that there are no real consequences
Reduces incentives for wrongdoing
Improves institutional credibility

questions.question_text: In ethical discourse, 'transparency without accountability' may be insufficient because:

options.option_text: Information alone does not ensure consequences for wrongdoing
Transparency always eliminates corruption fully
Accountability can work only in secrecy
Citizens cannot use information at all

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a key ethical role of civil society organisations in combating corruption?

options.option_text: Limiting citizen awareness
Monitoring governance, raising awareness and facilitating social audits
Supporting secrecy in administration
Discouraging whistle-blowers

questions.question_text: From an ethical governance perspective, 'open data' initiatives by governments are expected to:

options.option_text: Make data accessible only to a few insiders
Provide public access to non-sensitive government data in usable formats to enhance transparency and innovation
Increase secrecy in public affairs
Expose personal private data of citizens arbitrarily

questions.question_text: Which of the following reasons explains why corruption undermines human rights and development?

options.option_text: It guarantees equal access to services
It diverts resources from essential services, discriminates against the poor and erodes trust in institutions
It always increases efficiency
It ensures rule of law for all
None

questions.question_text: From an ethics viewpoint, 'name-and-shame' strategies against corruption must be used carefully because they may:

options.option_text: Always guarantee justice
Violate due process and harm reputations if based on unverified allegations
Replace judicial mechanisms completely
Never deter wrongdoing

questions.question_text: From an ethical perspective, which of the following is a desirable feature of internal reporting systems for corruption in public organisations?

options.option_text: Lack of confidentiality
Protection of reporters, clear procedures and impartial investigation
Automatic punishment of all who complain
Total absence of documentation

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the MOST appropriate indicator that anti-corruption reforms are effective in a particular department?

options.option_text: Increase in informal payments to staff
Improved service delivery, reduced complaints of bribery and strong disciplinary actions in proven cases
Complete absence of documented complaints due to fear
No audits conducted for several years

questions.question_text: From an ethics perspective, how does 'simplification of procedures' help reduce corruption?

options.option_text: By creating more opportunities for discretion
By reducing complexity, discretion and the need for intermediaries
By increasing the number of forms and approvals
By ensuring that citizens cannot understand procedures

questions.question_text: Which of the following MOST clearly shows misuse of 'public resources for private purposes'?

options.option_text: Using office car exclusively for official duties
Using government premises to run a private business
Using personal vehicle for official visits
Returning unspent public funds at the end of project

questions.question_text: From an ethical perspective, what is the primary expectation from media in the fight against corruption?

options.option_text: Suppress information about wrongdoing
Investigate and report corruption responsibly based on facts
Sensationalise unverified allegations for profit
Act only as a publicity agency for the government

questions.question_text: Ethical training of public officials regarding integrity and transparency should primarily focus on:

options.option_text: Only memorising penal provisions
Developing awareness of risks, fostering values and practising skills for ethical decision-making
Learning how to evade accountability
Ignoring real-life dilemmas

questions.question_text: From an ethical governance standpoint, 'time-bound service delivery laws' passed by many states aim to curb corruption by:

options.option_text: Allowing officials unlimited discretion in timing
Reducing scope for delay-based bribery and making officials answerable for delays
Increasing the number of approvals needed
Eliminating citizens’ right to complain

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a key ethical reason for ensuring 'fair and transparent recruitment' in public services?

options.option_text: To ensure only politically connected candidates are selected
To build a competent and honest civil service based on merit, reducing entry-point corruption
To reward those who pay for jobs
To maintain secrecy in selection processes

questions.question_text: An anti-corruption policy that focuses only on punishing lower-level staff but ignores high-level corruption is ethically problematic because it:

options.option_text: Strengthens overall deterrence
Creates perception of selective justice and undermines credibility of enforcement
Ensures equal accountability for all
Eliminates grand corruption completely

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of 'ethical resistance' to corruption by a public servant?

options.option_text: Accepting small bribes to maintain good relations
Refusing to comply with illegal orders and documenting dissent through proper channels
Ignoring rules to favour a friend
Destroying official records to hide irregularities

questions.question_text: From an ethical viewpoint, a strong 'code of conduct' for public servants should ideally:

options.option_text: Be unknown to employees
Clearly articulate expected behaviours, conflict-of-interest rules and consequences of violation
Be vague and non-binding
Encourage acceptance of gifts and favours
None

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements best captures the ethical relationship between 'corruption' and 'inequality' in society?

options.option_text: Corruption always reduces inequality
Corruption often exacerbates inequality by favouring those who can pay or influence decision-makers
Corruption has no effect on distribution of opportunities
Corruption always benefits the poorest first

questions.question_text: From an ethical governance standpoint, what is the key risk in excessive 'secrecy' laws without adequate public interest safeguards?

options.option_text: Improvement in transparency
Shielding corruption and abuse of power from public scrutiny
Strengthening of whistle-blowing
Facilitating social audits

questions.question_text: Which of the following combinations is MOST conducive to promoting integrity and transparency in public life?

options.option_text: High discretion, low accountability, weak enforcement
Clear rules, independent oversight, active civil society and ethical leadership
Opaque systems and fear of retaliation for complainants
Weak audit and no public participation

questions.question_text: Which of the following best illustrates the ethical value of 'leading by example' in anti-corruption efforts?

options.option_text: Senior officials demanding integrity from juniors but themselves engaging in corrupt acts
Senior officials strictly following rules, refusing favours and declaring assets honestly
Leaders remaining silent on corruption issues
Leaders discouraging audits to maintain harmony

questions.question_text: Ultimately, integrity and transparency in governance are essential because they:

options.option_text: Benefit only officials
Build citizens’ trust, protect rights and ensure fair use of public resources for common good
Make administration unnecessarily complicated
Are obstacles to development
None
